awd_titl_txt: Frustration and Spin Fluctuations in Itinerant Magnets
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL ABSTRACT
This project, supported by the Condensed Matter Physics program of the Division of the Materials Research, presents a systematic way to design and discover magnetic materials belonging to a rare class of compounds, those formed with non-magnetic constituents: itinerant magnets. Magnetic materials are ubiquitous in our modern world and they are at the heart of many technologies including memory storage, magnetic resonance imaging (MRIs) etc. While the applications of magnetic materials are clear, our fundamental understanding of their properties remains largely unknown, especially for those magnetic systems formed without known magnetic elements (like iron or rare earths). The understanding of the purely itinerant magnetism limit is inhibited by the scarcity of relevant compounds, which this project seeks to design and synthesize. An added novelty of this approach is the study of effects in itinerant magnets, related to the crystal structure. This proposal supports the training of undergraduate and graduate student researchers in the areas of crystal growth and materials characterization. The PI continues her ongoing outreach initiatives, which include open houses and science demonstrations at local public schools in addition to developing a new "science a la carte" program, aimed at complex science concepts accessible to young students.

Technical abstract:
This NSF proposal emphasizes experimental investigations of itinerant magnetic systems to explore the role of spin fluctuations and magnetic frustration in compounds without magnetic elements. New discoveries of two itinerant antiferromagnets, together with the only two known ferromagnets without magnetic elements, offer a platform for two main research thrusts: the study of correlations between the dimensionality and spin fluctuations of itinerant magnets, particularly in the quantum critical regime; the development of a new paradigm for frustration in itinerant magnetic systems. This project addresses issues currently at the forefront of condensed matter physics, such as quantum criticality and attendant non-Fermi liquid effects, and also frustration as a new dimension in a generalized phase diagram for quantum criticality. Our program aligns with the imperious societal need for design and discovery of new materials, while training the new generation of crystal growers. The PI continues her program providing hands-on science experience through the lab "open houses" for the public, training high school students and teachers through internships, and by implementing a "science a la carte" program for schools in the Houston area. This program provides science kits in line with the school science curriculum, together with demonstrations by the PI and her students, and handouts, aimed at fostering learning beyond the classroom.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
- Quantum critical point in Ti3Cu4: We discovered the new itinerant antiferromagnet without magnetic elements Ti3Cu4, and found evidence of a field-induced quantum critical point (QCP) around 5 Tesla. Growing high quality single crystals of this compound allowed us to perform detailed low temperature measurements and critical scaling analysis from magnetization, specific heat and electrical transport. Moreover, we developed a new technique to characterize magnetic systems in the quantum critical regime: magnetocaloric effect (MCE) measurements provided the thermodynamic probe for the field-induced quantum phase transition in the itinerant antiferromagnet Ti3Cu4. All thermodynamic and transport measurements in Ti3Cu4 show critical scaling consistent with a second order phase transition associated with the QCP at Hc ~ 5 T.

- High temperature fluctuations in YCo2: we grew the first single crystals of the itinerant magnet YCo2. The magnetic properties of this compound are qualitatively analogous to those of SrCo2As2, where competing ferro- and antiferro-magnetic interactions have been shown to result in itinerant magnetic frustration. Recently, quantum geometry has been proposed to yield emergent states (superconductivity, unconventional magnetic order) from flat bands. We performed detailed DFT calculations and neutron experiments on both YCo2 and Y(Co1-xAlx)2 single crystals, to establish the effect of the flat band resulting from the pyrochlore Co sublattice. 

- Topological spin textures in EuAl2Ga2: following on our previous studies of the charge density wave in Eu(Ga,Al)4 compounds, we focused on the stoichiometric EuAl2Ga2. We discovered that this centrosymmetric square lattice hosts topological spin textures, making this the first Eu-based skyrmion host material. The closures related to the pandemic have slowed down these experiments significantly. However, we have recently got zero field neutron diffraction data providing direct evidence for the non-collinear spin structure in the ordered state. In-field neutron experiemnst are planned to map out the entire phase diagram, and in particular the transition through the skyrmion phase. We observed topological Hall effect in multiple magnetic phases of EuAl2Ga2. 

- We synthesized new candidate itinerant magnets SrAl4, SrAl2Ga2 and SrGa4. The study or the Sr(Al1-xGax)4 series revealed a related series with magnetic Eu instead of Sr, which then led us to an ample new study of correlated topological systems in the Eu(Al1-xGax)4 series. Related to this, we developed a quantum oscillation analysis for higher harmonic signals to characterize the angular dependence of SdH oscillations in SrGa2 and BaGa2 and determine the signatures of non-trivial Berry phases in square net compounds.

- We used QED cavity for tuning of the superconducting state of a HTSC thin film YBCO

- EuGa4: We developed a theoretical model accounting for non-saturating (very large) magnetoresistance in Weyl nodal ring systems. Applied to EuGa4, where we observed such non-saturating MR, we were able to reconcile the magnetotransport with the presence of Weyl nodal rings in this compound.

- CeRhAl4Si2, EuRhAl4Si2 and EuIrAl4Si2: We grew single crystals of these square net magnets with Kondo interactions or multi-spin correlations mediated by itinerant electrons. In the Eu compounds in particular, we identified an induced moment on the Si sublattice, resulting in an unusual “devil’s staircase” in the magnetization isotherms.
